results.display_title: Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club
results.headline: A Cranky Bonding Agent for Society’s Oil and Water
results.summary_short: Thrown together after their children misbehave in school, five very different women form a support group in “Tyler Perry’s The Single Moms Club.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club

results.headline: A Documentary on Battling Addiction’s Powerful Pull
results.summary_short: Greg Williams directed “The Anonymous People,” a documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Anonymous People

results.headline: Writing a New Romance
results.summary_short: In “Shirin in Love,” a young Iranian-American journalist who feels lukewarm about her fiancé rushes headlong into a relationship with the son of an interview subject.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shirin in Love

results.headline: South Korean School for Scandal
results.summary_short: In the South Korean drama “Tabloid Truth,” the death of an actress linked to a married politician is only the start of the action.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tabloid Truth

results.headline: Their Life Is a Cabaret, With Freedom in Vulgarity
results.summary_short: Eight cabaret performers are profiled in “Exposed,” which features snippets of their performances, merging shock and showmanship.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exposed

results.headline: Preserving Culture in the Amazon
results.summary_short: “Xingu” tells how three brothers, hoping to protect indigenous people in the Amazon, helped create a sprawling national park in Brazil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Xingu

results.headline: Murder, Mentoring and Masochism in Japan
results.summary_short: Sion Sono’s “Guilty of Romance” looks at three women — a detective, a literature professor and a wife — each with ties to episodes of sexual abuse.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guilty of Romance

results.headline: A Getaway Unravels the Ties That Bind
results.summary_short: In “Le Week-End,” Nick and Meg, a long-married couple, revisit Paris to try to put the spark back in their marriage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Week-End

results.headline: In Japan, Two Teenagers Bond in a Chaotic, Violent World
results.summary_short: “Himizu,” directed by Sion Sono, is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present, made soon after the 2011 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Himizu

results.headline: Poignant in Tooth and Claw
results.summary_short: “Ernest & Celestine,” about a mouse and a bear, offers the childhood comfort of a miniature world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ernest & Celestine

results.headline: Oil Money, and Where It Flows
results.summary_short: Rachel Boynton’s documentary “Big Men” is about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana and the perfect storm of avarice that develops around it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Men

results.headline: A Local Girl Who Made It Returns
results.summary_short: Fans wanted more of the canceled TV show “Veronica Mars,” and with the help of a Kickstarter campaign, much of the old cast, including Kristen Bell, is back in Neptune in a feature film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Veronica Mars

results.headline: The Killer Online
results.summary_short: In “The Den,” directed by Zach Donohue, a graduate student researching video-chat culture witnesses a murder online.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Den

results.headline: Young Drifter
results.summary_short: In “The Cold Lands,” an 11-year-old boy flees into the forest after his mother’s death, shunning society until he meets another drifter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cold Lands

results.headline: Trying to Take What Isn’t Theirs
results.summary_short: In “The Art of the Steal,” Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell are half-brothers and part of an art theft ring.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Art of the Steal

results.headline: Fast Cars, and Racing for Revenge
results.summary_short: Aaron Paul stars in “Need for Speed,” a B movie based on a video game series that might be best seen at a drive-in.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Need for Speed

results.headline: A Spelling Bee Bully With Decades on His Rivals
results.summary_short: “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman’s feature-directing debut, is a would-be gonzo comedy with a tough exterior and a marshmallow center.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Words

results.headline: When Your Twin Is Far More Interesting
results.summary_short: In “Enemy,” directed by Denis Villeneuve, Jake Gyllenhaal plays a history professor who sees his double and starts stalking him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enemy

results.headline: Some Things Go Bump in the Daytime, Too
results.summary_short: “Dark House” is a horror movie with a rural setting by Victor Salva, director of “Jeepers Creepers.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark House

results.headline: A Tough Day Being French (She Needs a Cigarette)
results.summary_short: Emmanuelle Bercot’s “On My Way” stars Catherine Deneuve as a woman who goes out for a pack of cigarettes and ends up driving all over rural France.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On My Way
